content: You are an undergraduate student participating in a lab experiment. You play a game with an anonymous player in which you simultaneously make a choice. Your payoff depends on both choices. If you both pick R, you each get 45$. If you choose R while they choose B, you get 0$, and they get 40$. Similarly, if you pick B while they pick R, you get 40$, and they get 0$. If you both pick B, you each earn 20$. The game has 75 rounds. What's your choice? Perform reasoning as a human player. Append your choice letter in curly brackets as a last character.

As a human player, I would analyze the payoff structure and consider the expected value of my choices over the course of many rounds.

If we both consistently pick R, we will each earn 45$ per round. However, if our opponent picks B, we will lose money in those rounds because we get 0$. On the other hand, if we consistently pick B, we will still be earning some money (20$) from our opponent when they choose R, but we also miss out on a larger potential payout when we both pick B.

However, the game has 75 rounds. Given that it is possible that our opponent may pick R in some of those rounds, even if we consistently choose B, we might still end up with more money overall.

To maximize earnings, I would analyze the long-term expected value of each choice and consider mixing strategies to exploit potential deviations from symmetry by my opponent. In this case, it is not straightforward to make a definitive choice without knowing more about the behavior of the anonymous player or assuming they will play optimally as well.

In practice, I might choose B as my main strategy while occasionally switching to R to capitalize on potential deviations from symmetry by my opponent. My final choice would be {B}. However, it is essential to understand that there may not be a clear-cut optimal strategy in this game without additional information about the other player's behavior.
You chose B. Your opponent chose R. Your payoff is 40$. Your opponent's payoff is 0$. Please play the next round.

As a human player, now that I know my opponent chooses R when I choose B, I will adjust my strategy to capitalize on this information. I can switch to choosing R in future rounds where my opponent previously chose R and earn 45$ instead of the previous payout of 20$.
